title: Terms and requirements for use cases
body: That tool must be used only in terminal app inside launched gui session, or it must support strict tui modes like grub or putty ssh?
author: EgorWeders

comments.body: I don't really understand the question, but right now the tool does work in in strict tui environments, I have tested it on arch linux tty and it works great. A problem might be the ansi-colors but they're easily overridden by setting the `LSR_COLORS` environment variable to use other colors or no colors at all.

> I have tested it on arch linux tty and it works great.

I asked about it,ty.
What is the need of the CMakeLists.txt file, if the project uses Make as its build system?

Cmake is better. It supports more convenient ways to include dirs ( for example : add include paths for libs in plain makefile (need to modify compile flags for each complier) and in cmake you can just add " include_directories()"). It is your choice, what to support, but cmake is standard for crossplatform.

Also, cmakelists.txt can be parsed with ide (i use qt creator).
I can commit fixes as different commit without cmake
I will remove the CMakeLists file for now, I believe that there is no need for using CMake right now. Maybe in the future, but I think sticking to Makefiles right now will do it.
